Award.AwardTitle: Second International IEEE Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and medical Sciences (ICCABS) - Travel Awards

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Computational techniques are revolutionizing the way in which research is conducted in science and engineering. However, even in domains that seem closely liked, such as biology, medicine, and drug discovery, computing science research advances are not broadly disseminated and do not become widely known. This conference would bring together computational scientists and domain experts to explore current results and to foster collaborations. A set of outstanding researchers from around the world have agreed to structure this new effort. The three day meeting meeting, in Las Vegas Nevada, would have participation by students through travel grants. This building of the next generation of computing science in different application areas is one of the key outcomes of this meeting. In addition, the selected papers will be made available online. In addition, some of the papers will be published through BioMed Central, which has reduced the costs for this meeting. Bringing together academic and industry researchers to consider the latest advances in computational methods will promote the rapid transfer of results from research to products and technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Computational techniques are revolutionizing the way in which research is conducted in science and engineering. Unsurpassed advances have been made in various areas. This is particularly true in the domains of biology, medicine, and drug discovery. It is not enough if advances are made in these areas in isolation. These communities have to work together to help each other and come up with the best possible diagnosis tools, treatment procedures, and drugs for various diseases. Even though a number of conferences exist today in the general area of bioinformatics, they focus on computational biology to a large extent. Intellectual merits of this project lie in the fact that ICCABS has the goal of bringing together scientists in all the three areas and hence serving as a platform for bridging the research efforts in these areas.

Broader Impacts: Funds from NSF were used to support 31 graduate students and one Keynote speaker. The graduate students supported came from 17 different universities in the USA, Canada, and Germany. The conference was a great success as reported by the attendees. There were around 100 registrants who attended the conference. All the talks were well attended and appreciated.

Outcomes: The Conference was held over a 2.5-day span, following usual Conference conventions. There were two parallel sessions. The technical program included 25 extended abstracts selected by the Program Committee from a number of 55 full submissions received in response to the call for papers. The program also included 8 invited talks and 15 poster presentations, and featured keynote talks by two distinguished speakers. David Sankoff from the University of Ottawa spoke on fractionation, the process that results in the loss of one copy from almost all pairs of duplicated genes created by whole genome duplication, and Pavel Pevzner from the University of California at San Diego spoke on de novo sequencing of novel peptide antibiotics by tandem mass spectrometry. Invited talks were delivered by eight well-established and highly successful researchers: Srinivas Aluru, Tanya Berger-Wolf, Vladimir Filkov, Bjarni Halldórsson, Maricel Kann, Vipin Kumar, Rachel O’Neill, and Roded Sharan. Additionally, the technical program included 15 invited talks presented as a part of the 2nd Workshop on Computational Advances for Next Generation Sequencing (CANGS) which was held in conjunction with ICCABS 2012.

 

Authors of accepted papers submitted full research articles. These papers were put together to produce the Proceedings for IEEE. These proceedings are available online in the IEEE Xplore digital library. Each participant was supplied with a copy of the Proceedings in a flash memory stick. Out of the full papers accepted for presentation in the conference, expanded versions of 20 were invited for two journal special issues. In particular, 8 papers were invited for a special issue of BMC Bioinformatics and another 12 papers were invited for a special issue of BMC Genomics. One of the papers invited for BMC Genomics has been rejected and all the other 19 papers have been accepted. These two special issues were edited by Sorin Istrail, Ion Mandoiu, Mihai Pop, Sanguthevar Rajasekaran, and John Spouge. These papers went through an additional set of reviews. We are glad to note that these two special issues have been finalized recently and the final versions of these papers have been submitted to the publisher. We expect that these special issues will go online soon.
